citeinfo.title: SO2 emission rates from Kilauea Volcano, Hawaii (2014-2017)

citeinfo.origin: Elias, T., Kern, C., Horton, K. A., Sutton, A. J., Garbeil, H.
citeinfo.title: Measuring SO2 emission rates at Kīlauea Volcano, Hawaii, using an array of upward-looking UV spectrometers, 2014-2017

descript.abstract:
This report documents the SO2 emission rates for the period 2014-2017, from the summit and East Rift Zone eruptions of Kīlauea, along with the wind or plume speed and direction data used to calculate the emission rates. The Kīlauea summit SO2 emission rates are reported every ten seconds, as measured by a novel configuration of 10 fixed, upward looking UV spectrometers (FLYSPEC array), and for days with at least 2 hours of data, the daily means are reported. The plume or wind speeds used to calculate the emission rates are measured by cross correlation of plume features (see William-Jones and others (2006)) or by ground-based anemometer (SDH) and are reported with the emission rates. When the SDH ground based wind speed is used, the plume speed and direction in the summit 10-s emission rate data file is specified with the text identifier ‘SDH’. The SDH wind vector data are included as a separate file. There is a discrepancy of 22% between coincident array measured plume speed and ground-based wind speed. Since wind speed is a direct multiplier in calculating emission rate, when SDH winds are used, the emission rates have been adjusted by +22% (6.3% of valid data). Several data filters have been applied to the FLYSPEC array data, to minimize erroneous values due to instrumental issues or environmental conditions. We present emission rates 1) collected at wind speeds between 2.5 and 20 m/s, as we are confident that these conditions provide a reasonably compact plume that exhibit minimal effects from atmospheric wind shear 2) ≥ 300 metric tonnes per day (t/d), which is the detection limit of the FLYSPEC array. This limit is based on the minimum column amount that we are confident indicates the presence of the plume (350 ppmm), and minimum wind conditions that produce a measurable plume (2.5 m/s). Summit emission rate values <300 t/d are noted as bdl (below detection limit) 3) without random outliers that change by over 50,000 t/d in a single 10-second interval (2 data points). Very high values (tens of thousands of t/d) occur occasionally and may reflect challenging measurement conditions, or actual very high SO2 emissions.
Traditional campaign road-based traverse SO2 emission rate measurements are reported for the ERZ eruption. These data are measured along the Chain of Craters Road, within Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, and follow the protocol previously documented in USGS Open-File Report 2012-1107. These data are irregularly spaced (days to weeks), as they are dependent on appropriate wind and weather conditions, and staff availability, for successful measurement. The ERZ campaign style emission rate data include the wind vector used to calculate the emission rate value, and a quality code to help identify conditions that may affect the data quality.
While the FLYSPEC array provides the best estimate of emission rates for the Kīlauea summit for 2014-2017, campaign road-based traverses were also collected at the summit along Crater Rim. Moderate resolution spectra of scattered solar radiation were recorded using a FLYSPEC (2014-2017) or DOAS (2017) instrument mounted on a vehicle in upward-looking geometry. The instrument setup is described in Horton and others (2006), Galle and others (2003), and Elias and others (2012).
SumRdTraverseSpectra_2014-2017.zip contains dated folders with the individual spectra collected during the plume traverses. The incident spectral radiance was measured between 260 and 410 nm at a spectral resolution of 0.5 nm. Spectral intensity is reported in digital counts, where each count is linearly related to radiance (> 99% linearity).
For the FLYSPEC instrument, the recorded spectra are saved in a binary file format (scan*.bin files). A new scan*.bin file is saved each time a new set of measurements (typically containing multiple traverses) is begun. Each binary file contains an array of spectra. Each spectrum is composed of an array of 2048 pixel intensities stored in single precision floating point format (4 bytes). Individual spectra can be addressed within a binary file by accessing the file position N × 8192, where N represents the desired spectrum number.
Each binary file is accompanied by a scan*.txt file saved in ASCII format. The *.txt file contains metadata for each spectrum stored in the associated scan*.bin file. Each row of text represents an individual spectrum. The text columns ascribe each spectrum with an identifying number, year, month, day, hour, minute, second, GPS time, latitude (in degrees), longitude (in degrees), altitude (in meters), and preliminary SO2 column density in ppmm (column 16 and column 19 before and after Apr 9, 2014, respectively). The preliminary SO2 column densities are obtained by comparing incident radiance spectra with spectra obtained with SO2 gas calibration cells inserted into the light path (see Horton (2006) for details). These preliminary values may not be accurate for the summit due to complex light path distributions occurring in and around the dense gas and aerosol clouds present near Kilauea’s Overlook vent. See Elias et. al. (2018) and Kern et. al. (2012) for further details.
For the mobile DOAS data collection, each spectrum is saved in a *.std ASCII file. These files begin with a 3-line header specifying the file format and the number of spectral channels. Then, 2048 individual upward-looking radiances are reported. The spectral data is followed by metadata associated with each spectrum, including Longitude (decimal degrees), Latitude (decimal degrees), Altitude (m), Exposure Time of the spectral acquisition (ms), and NumScans which reports the number of individual spectra co-added together to form this reported measurement spectrum. The rest of the reported metadata is for internal use when opening the spectra in the freely available DOASIS software (https://doasis.iup.uni-heidelberg.de/bugtracker/projects/doasis/). The mobile DOAS data folders are identified with a DOAS* naming convention.

descript.purpose: The measurements were collected to analyze the spectral absorption of sulfur dioxide (SO2) in scattered solar radiation passing through the volcanic plume. Together with a geometrical plume model, these measurements allowed the amount of SO2 released from the Kīlauea ERZ and summit eruptions to be calculated. See the associated manuscript in Frontiers in Earth Science for more information.
descript.supplinf: NA values indicate periods when weather or instrument conditions were insufficient to retrieve valid emission rates. Some valid SO2 emission rates are reported though the plume direction data is listed as NA. Although a valid plume direction was originally used to calculate the emission rate, the plume direction data was not successfully retained in the database.

attracc.attraccr: Spectral data has a signal to noise ratio of 250:1. Stray light is specified to less than 0.1% at 435 nm. Corrected linearity of response is better than 99%. The spectrometer’s wavelength calibration depends slightly on the optical bench temperature and is best derived for each individual spectrum from the pixel position of known solar Fraunhofer lines.

dataqual.logic: The SO2 emission rate data have been filtered for random outliers that occur due to instrumental issues or poor measurement (atmospheric) conditions. The minimum detection limit for the array is considered to be 300 t/d. This is based on a conservative estimate of minimum column amount indicating the presence of the plume, and minimum wind conditions that produce a measurable, consolidated plume. The data have been filtered to include only emission rates collected under reasonable wind speeds (2.5-20 m/s) which result in measurable plumes that are sufficiently compact, and are not influenced by excessive wind shear. The SDH wind speed data have been filtered to eliminate physically unreasonable values for local conditions, or for determining a reasonable SO2 emission rate (wind speeds or gusts over 100 m/s). For the raw spectra provided in SumRdTraverseSpectra_2014-2017.zip, additional processing presented as ppmm in scan*.txt files may be inaccurate due to radiative transfer issues (see Kern et. al. 2012).
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

procstep.procdesc: FLYSPEC radiance spectra collected at 1-second intervals are used to calculate column path values using manufacturer supplied software (Lapfly by FLYSPEC inc.) as described in Horton, K. A., Williams-Jones, G., Garbeil, H., Elias, T., Sutton, A. J., Mouginis-Mark, P., . . . Clegg, S. (2006). Real-time measurement of volcanic SO2 emissions: validation of a new UV correlation spectrometer (FLYSPEC). Bulletin of Volcanology, 68(4), 323-327.

Emission rates were calculated using locally collected wind or plume speed data, and manufacturer supplied software. For the ERZ data, the FLYSPEC inc. supplied software FluxCalc was used as described in Horton, K. A., Williams-Jones, G., Garbeil, H., Elias, T., Sutton, A. J., Mouginis-Mark, P., . . . Clegg, S. (2006). Real-time measurement of volcanic SO2 emissions: validation of a new UV correlation spectrometer (FLYSPEC). Bulletin of Volcanology, 68(4), 323-327, and Elias, T., & Sutton, A. J. (2012). Sulfur dioxide emission rates from Kilauea Volcano, Hawai`i, 2007–2010. U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 2012-1107, 25 p. For the Summit array data, the FLYSPEC inc.supplied software tcpServer calculates emission rates as described in Horton, K. A., Garbeil, H., Sutton, A. J., Elias, T., & Businger, S. (2012). Early monitoring results from the Halema`uma`u Vog Measurement and Prediction FLYSPEC array [abs.]. American Geophysical Union, 2012 Chapman Conference Abstracts, p. 48. and Businger, Steven; Huff, Roy; Pattantyus, Andre; Horton, Keith; Sutton, A; Elias, Tamar; Cherubini, Tiziana. 2015, Observing and Forecasting Vog Dispersion from Kīlauea Volcano, Hawai‘i. Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society 96(10):150520105846003.

Daily emission rates were calculated from the 10-second FLYSPEC array values by averaging all valid data for a given day. Averages are presented for days with at least 2 hours of valid 10-s data, which reduces the likelihood of atypical conditions influencing the average.

For raw spectra provided in SumRdTraverseSpectra_2014-2017.zip, column densities in ppmm presented in the scan*.txt files were evaluated using the calibration cell and clear sky spectra, but may be inaccurate due to radiative transfer issues (see the associated manuscript in Frontiers in Earth Science, and Kern et. al. 2012 for more information).

attr.attrdef: A text identifier that signifies the quality of the emission rate data based on wind, weather and plume conditions and geometry.

edom.edomvd: A - BEST - strong, steady, well constrained wind conditions, and a compact, consistent plume shape.
B - GOOD - moderately consistent plume shape and location of plume on road. Moderately strong, uniform winds.
C - ACCEPTABLE - variable plume location/shape. WS/WD variable/poorly constrained. Partial plumes, meteoric cloud >50%, wind shear, instrument issues included in this category.
